Title: An Analysis of Data Corruption in the Storage Stack
AuthorList: Lakshmi N. Bairavasundaram, Garth R. Goodson, Bianca Schroeder, Andrea C. Arpaci-Dusseau, Remzi H. ArpaciDusseau. FAST ’08, San Jose, CA, February 2008.
Description: Our own work analyzing how often disks actually corrupt your data. Not often, but sometimes! And thus something a reliable storage system must consider.

Title: Disk Shadowing
AuthorList: D. Bitton and J. Gray. VLDB 1988.
Description: One of the ﬁrst papers to discuss mirroring, therein called "shadowing”.

Title: Striping in a RAID level 5 disk array
AuthorList: Peter M. Chen and Edward K. Lee. SIGMETRICS 1995.
Description: A nice analysis of some of the important parameters in a RAID-5 disk array.

Title: Row-Diagonal Parity for Double Disk Failure Correction
AuthorList: P. Corbett, B. English, A. Goel, T. Grcanac, S. Kleiman, J. Leong, S. Sankar. FAST ’04, February 2004.
Description: Though not the ﬁrst paper on a RAID system with two disks for parity, it is a recent and highly-understandable version of said idea. Read it to learn more.

Title: Journal-guided Resynchronization for Software RAID
AuthorList: Timothy E. Denehy, A. Arpaci-Dusseau, R. Arpaci-Dusseau. FAST 2005.
Description: Our own work on the consistent-update problem. Here we solve it for Software RAID by integrating the journaling machinery of the ﬁle system above with the software RAID beneath it.

Title: File System Design for an NFS File Server Appliance
AuthorList: Dave Hitz, James Lau, Michael Malcolm. USENIX Winter 1994, San Francisco, California, 1994.
Description: The sparse paper introducing a landmark product in storage, the write-anywhere ﬁle layout or WAFL ﬁle system that underlies the NetApp ﬁle server.

Title: Synchronized Disk Interleaving
AuthorList: M.Y. Kim. IEEE Transactions on Computers, Volume C-35: 11, November 1986.
Description: Some of the earliest work on RAID is found here.

Title: Small Disk Arrays – The Emerging Approach to High Performance
AuthorList: F. Kurzweil. Presentation at Spring COMPCON ’88, March 1, 1988, San Francisco, California.

Title: Redundant Arrays of Inexpensive Disks
AuthorList: D. Patterson, G. Gibson, R. Katz. SIGMOD 1988. This is considered the RAID paper, written by famous authors Patterson, Gibson, and Katz.
Description: The paper has since won many test-of-time awards and ushered in the RAID era, including the name RAID itself!

Title: Providing Fault Tolerance in Parallel Secondary Storage Systems
AuthorList: A. Park, K. Balasubramaniam. Department of Computer Science, Princeton, CS-TR-O57-86, November 1986.

Title: Disk Striping
AuthorList: K. Salem, H. Garcia-Molina. IEEE International Conference on Data Engineering, 1986.
Description: And yes, another early RAID work. There are a lot of these, which kind of came out of the woodwork when the RAID paper was published in SIGMOD.

Title: Byzantine Generals in Action: Implementing Fail-Stop Processors
AuthorList: F.B. Schneider. ACM Transactions on Computer Systems, 2(2):145154, May 1984.
Description: Finally, a paper that is not about RAID! This paper is actually about how systems fail, and how to make something behave in a fail-stop manner.
